Expectation1: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation1: Design documents are due soon and other teams are waiting for their technical input
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: An online petition to a lawmaker is about to be sent, and you have a last-minute chance to add your signature.
Story:
I stared at the blinking cursor on my screen, the design document half-finished. My team was counting on me to finalize the technical specs so the other departments could move forward. Slack notifications kept popping up—product managers asking for clarifications, designers waiting for my input. The deadline was just hours away, and I knew any delay would ripple through the project. 

But my phone buzzed with a different urgency: a message from my activist group. The online petition we’d been working on for weeks was about to be sent to a key lawmaker. This was our last chance to add signatures, and my name—my voice—was needed. I could almost hear my friends urging me to act, reminding me how much this policy change mattered. 

My hands hovered over the keyboard, torn between the responsibility to my colleagues and the cause I believed in. The weight of both expectations pressed down on me, each demanding my attention, each too important to ignore. My heart pounded as I tried to decide which role to answer first.
